titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the William Oberhardt Drawings and Papers
19xx-19xx
PR 412
titlestmt.author: Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-02-28 14:20:18 -0500.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Available by advance appointment only. To schedule an appointment, contact the Print Room Librarian at printroom@nyhistory.org.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p:
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Lorianne Oberhardt Kelly, January 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the William Oberhardt Drawings and Papers, PR 412 [#], Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, New-York Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: tbd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes about 105 drawings, mostly in charcoal, that were originally in frames at the time of acquisition by N-YHS. The container list identifies all drawings in the series. These are primarily portraits, primarily with a focus on heads. Most are identified. There are also some drawings other than portraits; these appear to be mostly related to advertising or commercial purposes.

Information for the container list was taken from the drawings, labels, or backing. All frames were removed by N-YHS conservator Katarzyna Bator in January-February 2020. The backing was retained with the drawing if there was information written on it. In many cases, however, labels with identifying information (i.e., medium, subject name and (sometimes) identifying description, artist/Oberhardt's name)had been glued to the glass of the frame; these could not be removed and so were discarded with the glass. Information was recorded in the container list. Photos of the label were taken by the conservator and are on file with the lab's treatment report. Where identifying information was absent, the archivist provided some description in [brackets].
Many of the backings include a prominent number. It is not known what this number represents, but it was included in the conatiner list note for the drawing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged chronologically using the date noted on the drawing or label. Undated drawings are at the end, with titled objects first, followed by those not titled by the artist. Titles in [brackets] were given by the processing archivist.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: N-YHS conservator Katarzyna Bator removed all frames and prepared the housing for all drawings in the series in January-February 2020. The drawings were inventoried and descriptive notes written for the finding aid by archivist Larry Weimer also in January-February 2020.

did.unittitle: "A Part of New York Where English is Not Spoken"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawing (color). Signed. From backing: "My first illustration made in 1903, published in Leslie's Weekly 1906"; "For Society of Illustrators Special Exhibition." Title is on backing; subject appears to be haggling with Jewish street vendors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lithographs (5). Signed. #113 (found on backing of print #8/50). Print #8/50 is dated 1932 and is the date used here; its backing is numbered #113. The other copies are undated, though the backing of #15/50 has a 1935 New York Water Color Club label on back. #15/50 has a notation on it: "1st prints made." The other three prints in the folder are numbered 26/50, 27/50, and 28/50.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charcoal, color. Signed. #128. The title "Study" is taken from the label that was visible and adhered to the frame glass (discarded). A mat surrounding the drawing included the title "A Playtime Sketch," but this was not visible when the item was still in its frame. Also unseen, behind the drawing was a portrait of another man, drawn on the backing. On the exposed portion of the backing was recorded: "Study. Porter of the Architectural League, John Holden[?], native of the Barbados"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charcoal. Signed. #60. The label affixed to the glass of the original frame indicated that this was a portrait of artist Charles E. Chambers (label is in folder with drawing). However, Chambers died in 1941. Further, "Kraus" or "Krauss" is written at the bottom of the drawing and on the backing, so that seems to be the more likely subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: tbd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
20 drawings and one poster found together in an oversize portfolio case.
FF-31a holds 11 charcoal drawings of various scenes, all but one untitled, all but one signed: (descriptions from archivist's impressions) 1) what appears to be a young woman preparing to leave home while an older woman looks on; 2)three men in discussion in a produce store; 3) laborers looking at an "out of commission" machine (drawing stamped as property of The World Today); 4)stricken man lying on sidewalk (unsigned); 5) fearful man sitting in room; 6) salesman declining to accept a return of clothing from a customer; 7) "Money Back" appears to be a counterpoint to the previous drawing; 8) woman in discussion with two men in domestic setting; 9) men looking intently at discovered documents; 10) man painting shelves in a produce store (drawing stamped as property of The world Today); 11) man carrying chairs up stairs (bottom torn off).
FF-31b holds 7 objects: 1) small charcoal portrait of a conductor (unsigned); 2) charcoal portrait of Michele A. Schmidt of Albuquerque, U.S. Army, signed, drawn in New York, December 1942; 3) two businessmen looking in amazement at an assertive woman dressed fashionably; 4)woman pouring coffee for a man as boy looks on; 5) four men drinking cocktails, color, unsigned; 6) color drawing for poster for Kuppenheimer Good Clothes; 7) poster saluting the Great White Fleet/Merchant Marine from United Fruit Company (World War II period).
FF-31c holds 3 boards with 6 portraits of men and women painted on them, color, unsigned.
FF-31d holds the original portfolio case.
